Description: Ornamental evergreen shrub, 10-12ft height, zones 7-9.
Notes: Listed in the ACS Camellia Encyclopedia and featured on the Judge Arthur Solomon Camellia Trail in Savannah, Georgia. This elegant bicolor japonica produces striking blooms with crisp white petals delicately edged in soft pink. The lustrous dark green foliage provides excellent contrast to the flowers. Well-suited to Southern gardens, it thrives in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil. A reliable performer for landscape use with good cold hardiness through zone 7.

Description: RETICULATA HYBRID.; Registered 2013; 9-year chance seedling, first bloomed 2008; Spreading, at average growth rate
Notes: Adrienne Boueres is a reticulata hybrid camellia, registered in 2013. Grown as a 9-year-old chance seedling that first bloomed in 2008. The flowers are rose form double in form, displaying pink coloring. Plant growth is spreading, at average growth rate. Foliage features green leaves average 12. As a reticulata hybrid camellia, Adrienne Boueres is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Adrian Bourres' and is registered as 'Adrienne Boueres'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Notes: Amanda Ann is a japonica camellia originated by Steve and Gayle Lawrence of Tallahassee of Florida and registered by Randolph Maphis of Tallahassee, Florida and propagated by Randolph Maphis and Steve Lawrence, registered in 2014. First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. It arose as a chance seedling . The flowers are formal double in form, displaying dark red coloring. Growth is upright and spreading. Foliage features medium green leaves average 12. As a japonica camellia, Amanda Ann is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. Color / Form: White shading to Pink / Formal Double
Description: Miniature flowers; 15-year-old seedling first bloomed 1964; Dr. J.M. Habel, Suffolk VA; ACS #1658 (1980); late flowering.
Notes: Ann Clayton is a miniature camellia with delicate white flowers blushing to soft pink, representing a late-season japonica from American breeding programs of the 1960s. Originated as a chance seedling by Dr. J.M. Habel of Virginia, this cultivar was registered with the American Camellia Society and documented in their yearbook. It exemplifies the diversity of American camellia breeding that expanded the palette of available forms and colors beyond traditional Asian cultivars. (Source: American Camellia Society Encyclopedia)

Color / Form: Pure White with Creamy Center / Anemone Semi-double
Description: Flowers from pink buds; upright columnar form 8-10ft tall x 3-4ft wide; late fall to early winter bloom.
Notes: Autumn Rocket is a striking sasanqua prized for its elegant columnar habit and reliable fall-to-winter flowering. The cultivar produces deceptive pink buds that open to reveal pure white anemone-form flowers with softly creamy, pale yellow center petals accented by prominent golden stamens. This upright evergreen shrub grows 8-10 feet tall with a narrow 3-4-foot spread, ideal for vertical emphasis in garden design. Blooming from late fall into early winter, it performs best in full sun to part shade. Its distinctive columnar form and prolific white flowers have made it popular for modern camellia gardens. (Source: Camellia Forest Nursery)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 2011; Upright; Avery Warriner (Camellia sasanqua） ACS Registration #3092. This 12-year-old C. sasanqua chance seedling first bloomed in 2011. It was originated, registered, and propagated by Tom Warriner of Birmingham, Alabama. Bloom: The small sized 7.62cm x 2.54cm - 3.81cm semidouble form flower is medium pink fading to light pink at the petal edges. It has yellow anthers and yellow filaments.This profuse bloomer has consistent form. Plant: The plant habit is upright. The growth rate is vigorous. The plant is suitable for.
Notes: Avery Warriner is a japonica camellia, registered in 2011. It arose as a chance seedling . The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying graduated shading coloring. Growth is upright. Foliage features dark green leaves average 6. As a japonica camellia, Avery Warriner is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. Description: Anemone form with 12 petals and 30+ petaloids; large 10.2-11.4cm; Gene Phillips, Savannah GA; first bloomed 2017; ACS #2023.
Notes: Barbara Dooley is a recent introduction registered in 2023 by Gene Phillips of Gene's Nursery in Savannah, Georgia. This 14-year-old chance seedling derived from 'Royal Velvet' x 'Francis Eugene Phillips' demonstrates modern American breeding refinement with light red anemone-form blooms featuring a prominent central boss of yellow stamens. The substantial flowers measure over 10 centimeters with twelve large petals surrounding more than thirty ornamental petaloids. Vigorous growth with upright, dense habit and attractive dark green foliage makes it a contemporary addition to American camellia breeding heritage. (Source: American Camellia Society)

Description: Limited specific information; 'Bealei Rosea' variant of historical Bealei group; pink-flowered form.
Notes: Bealei Rosea belongs to an historic group of camellia cultivars with roots in traditional Asian breeding. The 'Rosea' designation indicates pink coloration in this double-flowered form, though comprehensive information on originator, precise size, registration date, and blooming season is not readily available in English-language sources. The Bealei group represents important heritage camellias that influenced subsequent breeding programs, but modern documentation for this specific pink variant appears limited. (Limited information available)

Color / Form: Light Pink with Deeper Pink Undersides / Semi-double
Description: Medium-large 8cm; 5 upright petals forming cup; Jones, Sierra Madre CA; US Plant Patent 605 (1953); late winter to early spring.
Notes: Berenice Boddy is a classic American camellia developed by Jones at Rancho del Descanso in Sierra Madre, California, representing an important watershed in mid-twentieth century breeding. Named for Mrs. Manchester Boddy, wife of the Los Angeles Daily News publisher, this cultivar received U.S. Plant Patent No. 605 in 1953. The elegant light pink flowers feature sophisticated color gradation with deeper pink on petal undersides and delicate white filaments. The Royal Horticultural Society honored it with an Award of Garden Merit in 1993. Most significantly, Berenice Boddy became a key parent plant in cold-hardy breeding programs, particularly the April series of hybrids, making it foundational to modern camellia genetics. (Source: RHS and International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1945; Alonza P. Boardman; Bushy, compact, vigorous grower; Fruitland Nursery Catalogue, 1945-1946, p.27: A large, deep pink, semi-double, 9-10 cm across, resembling ‘Donckelaeri’ (Masayoshi). Filaments white with a pink base and golden anthers; buds long and narrow. Leaves, light green, glossy, broad-ovate, 9.5 cm x 5.5 cm, long prominent apex, veins pronounced, serrations shallow. A bushy, compact, vigorous grower. Originated by Alonza P. Boardman, Georgia, USA from a seedling of unknown parents. Not to be confused with the cultivar Elizabeth Boardman. Sport Betty Boardman Variegated.

Description: Medium flowers; Charles Mason Hovey, Boston MA (1853); MHS Gold Medal 1853; RHS First Class Certificate 1878; late season; vigorous upright 6-7ft.
Notes: C.M. Hovey is a landmark American camellia that revolutionized the nation's horticultural history as the first camellia to win major U.S. honors. Named for pioneering Boston nurseryman and editor Charles Mason Hovey, this cultivar was exhibited at the Massachusetts Horticultural Society as 'Seedling I' in 1853, where it received their prestigious large gold medal. Haggerston's 1850 Magazine of Horticulture describes it as having 'form of flower rounded to the centre and full; petals broad and smooth, generally perfect; colour a bright crimson scarlet; size of flower, large.' By 1878, the Royal Horticultural Society awarded it a First Class Certificate. The formal double flowers are a rich dark red ranging into dark pinks, with perfectly arranged petals. Plant growth is vigorous with a slender, upright habit reaching 6-7 feet tall and 4-5 feet wide, featuring lustrous glossy deep-green foliage. Blooms late season (February-April). Has accumulated numerous synonyms including 'Colonel Firey', 'William S. Hastie', 'Firey King', 'Solaris', and 'Duc de Devonshire'. Variegated sports include 'Scarlett O'Hara' (dark red spotted white) and 'Bradford's Variegated'. Thomas Mecham wrote it was 'without exception the finest camellia of its color in cultivation.' Documented 150-year lifespans in Southern estates. Zones 8-9. (Source: International Camellia Register, International Camellia Society)

Color / Form: Medium Red / Rose-Form to Formal Double
Description: Large flowers; golden yellow stamens with white filaments; vigorous dense upright growth; dark green foliage; mid-season bloom.
Notes: Carol Humphrey is a Camellia japonica cultivar known primarily through its virus-variegated sport, 'Carol Humphrey Variegated', which produces striking large flowers in medium red dramatically blotched with white. The blooms display rose-form double to formal double arrangement with prominent golden yellow stamens and white filaments. Plant habit is vigorous with dense, upright growth and attractive dark green foliage. Flowers appear mid-season. The variegated form displays the characteristic virus-induced color pattern that creates distinctive red and white marbling, a coloration highly prized among collectors and exhibition growers. The cultivar is documented in the American Camellia Society Encyclopedia and the International Camellia Register, where it appears alongside related cultivars including 'Carol Betts', 'Carol Coleman', 'Carol Dickerson', and 'Carol Lynn'. Suitable for both landscape use and exhibition display. The heritage listing indicates it as the parent of the variegated sport, though detailed origination information for the solid form requires further research in historical ACS yearbooks. (Source: American Camellia Society Encyclopedia, International Camellia Register)

Description: Late flowering; round light green foliage; slow growth; Magnolia Gardens, Charleston SC; pre-1938.
Notes: Catherine Cathcart is a historic American cultivar with origins at the renowned Magnolia Gardens (now Magnolia Plantation and Gardens) in Charleston, South Carolina—one of the oldest camellia collections in the United States. First documented in Gerbing's Azalea Gardens Catalogue (1938-1939) as 'late flowering, full double pink, marbled with white' with 'round, light green foliage, slow growth.' The distinctive pink and white marbled coloration is characteristic of this antebellum-era cultivar. Colored illustration appears in Gerbing's 1945 'Camellias' (p.41), and black and white photo in Hertrich's 1959 'Camellias in the Huntington Gardens' vol.III (p.31). Has accumulated numerous synonyms over its long history including 'Leila', 'Lord Darby', 'San Antonio' (with misspelling 'San Antonia'), and 'Catherine Cathcart Variegated'. Orthographic errors include 'Catherine Catchart'. Specimens can be observed at Brookgreen Gardens in South Carolina and other historic Southern collections preserving antebellum-era camellias. The slow growth habit and distinctive marbled flowers make it a collector's piece representing early American camellia cultivation. (Source: International Camellia Register, Brookgreen Gardens)

Description: Small flowers; long flowering early season; moderate bushy growth; small neat leaves; Camellia Forest Nursery, Chapel Hill NC (2008).
Notes: Cecilia is a Camellia sasanqua cultivar introduced by Camellia Forest Nursery of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, first appearing in their 2008 catalog. The small pink formal double flowers bloom over an extended period in early season (typically fall), providing weeks of color when most gardens are winding down. The moderate growth rate produces a bushy, compact habit, while the characteristically small leaves give the plant a neat, refined appearance suitable for formal garden settings. As a sasanqua, Cecilia offers several advantages over japonica types: earlier bloom time extending the camellia season, better sun tolerance, and generally improved cold hardiness. The formal double form—unusual among sasanquas which more commonly produce single or semi-double flowers—makes this cultivar distinctive. Important note from the International Camellia Register: Not to be confused with the 1954 C. japonica 'Cecelia' (different spelling). Well-suited for hedging, foundation plantings, espalier against walls, or container culture where its compact habit and long flowering period can be appreciated. (Source: International Camellia Register, Camellia Forest Nursery)

The flower is of loose construction, there being two tiers of outer petals and a centre, sometimes cup-shaped, of semi-erect petals and petaloids. The petals are obovate, 4 cm long, wavy and notched. Yellow anthers,.
Notes: Mrs Freeman Weiss is a japonica camellia, registered in 1942. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying pink variegated coloring. Growth is vigorous, compact and upright. As a japonica camellia, Mrs Freeman Weiss is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Edelweiss' and is registered as 'Mrs Freeman Weiss'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #248 (1952); Open flat and others curl back slightly; Truett, 1952, American Camellia Yearbook , p.24: “Probably the best seedling that Mrs Paul Brock has is Edna Campbell. It is a semi-double with stamens and some petaloids. The colour is a dark, mahogany red. The petals are long and slender, some open flat and others curl back slightly. It has a very large flower and blooms mid-season to late.” Reg. No.248, American Camellia Yearbook, 1955. There is also a variegated form.
Notes: Edna Campbell is a japonica camellia, registered in 1952 (ACS Reg. No. 248). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying dark red variegated coloring. Growth is open flat and others curl back slightly. As a japonica camellia, Edna Campbell is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Edna Campbell Var.' and is registered as 'Edna Campbell'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1968; Open peony form with creped and notched petals and stamens, brok; American Camellia Yearbook, 1968, colour plate p.118: A hybrid developed by J. Howard Asper, Escondido, California, USA, from the species C.pitardii as the seed parent and C.japonica Tiffany as the pollen parent; 12.5 cm in diameter. A soft pink, open peony form with creped and notched petals and stamens, broken into fasciciles by erect, centre petals. Had previously been known as ‘Hazel Asper’. Blooms mid-season. See front cover SCCS, 1967, The Camellia Review, vol.29, No.2, and front cover New Zealand.
Notes: El Dorado is a japonica camellia, registered in 1968. First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink coloring. As a japonica camellia, El Dorado is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #151 (1971); Fred S. Tuckfield; Vigorous and upright; ACRS., 1971, Camellia News, No.43, p.36, Reg. No.151: Originated by Fred S. Tuckfield, Berwick, Victoria, Australia. Chance seedling from C.reticulata ‘Crimson Robe’, (Dataohong) that first flowered 1964. Plant habit vigorous and upright. The 12.5 cm, semi­double, mid-season bloom is currant red, (HCC.821 /2-/3). The dark green leaves are 12 cm long x 6 cm wide, oblong, reticulate, apiculate, and finely serrate. See colour photo, ACRS., 1977, Camellia News, No.66, p.19.
Notes: El Greco is a japonica camellia originated by Fred S. Tuckfield of Berwick, Victoria, Australia, registered in 1971 (ACS Reg. No. 151). It arose as a Chance seedling . The flowers are unknown in form, displaying red coloring. Growth is vigorous and upright. Foliage features dark green leaves are 12 cm long x 6 cm wide, oblong, reticulate, apiculate, and finely serrate. As a japonica camellia, El Greco is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'El Rojo' and is registered as 'El Greco'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #389 (1959); Mrs C.H. Maryott, Augusta, Georgia; 15-year chance seedling; American Camellia Yearbook, 1959, p.271, Reg. No.389: A 15 year old chance seedling, originated by Mrs C.H. Maryott, Augusta, Georgia, USA. Leaves dark green, 8.5 cm x 4 cm. Flowers are semi-double, 13.5 cm across x 5 cm deep with 12 petals and 5-20 petaloids. Colour is blush, streaked and flecked with deep pink. Flowers mid-season to late. Orthographic error: ‘Elenor Greenway’.
Notes: Eleanor Greenway is a japonica camellia originated by Mrs C.H. Maryott of Augusta, Georgia, USA, registered in 1959 (ACS Reg. No. 389). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 15-year-old chance seedling. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying red coloring. Each bloom features 12 petals and 20 petaloids. As a japonica camellia, Eleanor Greenway is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1942; Vigorous, loose, upright growth; SCCS., 1942, Classification of Camellia, p.3 as ‘Mrs Elenor McCowan’. No description. SCCS, 1950, The Camellia. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 2020; Robert Allen, South Carolina and registered and propagated by Robert Williams of Charleston, South Carolina; Upright and open
Notes: Anne Elizabeth Madsen is a japonica camellia originated by Robert Allen of South Carolina and registered and propagated by Robert Williams of Charleston, South Carolina, USA, registered in 2020. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1942; Opens rose form, when fully developed sta­mens show with mingled; Magnolia Gardens Catalogue, 1942-1943; Gerbings Azalea Gardens Catalogue, 1943-1944: This variegated Camellia opens rose form, when fully developed sta­mens show with mingled petaloids, semi-double. Often sporting solid rose-red flowers. Late flowering. Foliage, long, narrow, medium green. Originated at Magnolia Gardens, Charleston, South Carolina, USA. No.1354. American Camellia Yearbook , 1975, p236. A sport of "Elizabeth Dowd' that was :6rst observed in 1972 by W. F. Wilson, Jr.• Hammond, La. Has bloomed 100% true during a period of at least two years on several different plants. Plant growth habit, rate and leaves same as 'Elizabeth Down'. The rose form double bloom is solid rose-pink.
Notes: Elizabeth Dowd Rose is a japonica camellia originated by W.F. Wilson of Louisiana, USA, registered in 1975 (ACS Reg. No. 1354). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. It is a Sport of Elizabeth Dowd. The flowers are rose / standard in form, displaying pink coloring. Plant growth habit, rate and leaves same as 'Elizabeth Down'. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1951; Mr Hanger; Parentage: C.saluenensis x Alba Simplex; Peer, 1951, American Camellia Yearbook, p.114 as ‘Elizabeth Rothschild’: “Williamsii varieties of importance include ‘Elizabeth Rothschild’ (Adolphe Audusson x C.saluenensis) having large double, pink blossoms.” Originated by Mr Hanger, while at Exbury, England it has a medium size, semi-double, rose-pink flower in mid-season to late. Orthographic variants: ‘Elizabeth Rothschild’, ‘Elizabeth de Rotschild’, ‘Elizabeth de Rotschild’, ‘Elizabeth de Rothschild’. Under the name ‘Elizabeth’ G. Reuthe Ltd 1954 catalogue states that it is [C.saluenensis x Alba Simplex], which is actually Francis Hanger.
Notes: Elizabeth de Rothschild is a japonica camellia originated by Mr Hanger of while at Exbury, England it has a medium size, registered in 1951. First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. This cultivar was bred from the cross C.saluenensis x Alba Simplex. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying pink coloring. As a japonica camellia, Elizabeth de Rothschild is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. André, 1864, Plantes des Terres Bruyéres..., p.243: Very beautifully imbricated flower, carmine pink; all the petals clearly ribboned with metallic white. Description: CULTIVAR NOT FOUND: No authoritative record located in the International Camellia Register or American Camellia Society Encyclopedia for 'Eva's Rainbow'. Verify spelling and check for possible synonyms or local designations.
Notes: Research was conducted for 'Eva's Rainbow' (listed locally as 'Eva's Rainbow' with epithet ''). The International Camellia Register (camellia.iflora.cn) was queried but returned no matching cultivar record. The American Camellia Society Encyclopedia was also checked without success. This cultivar may be an unregistered local selection, a seedling that was never formally registered, or it may be listed under a different name or spelling. Possible steps for verification: (1) Check ACS Yearbooks for historical registrations; (2) Contact the originator or local camellia society for provenance information; (3) Compare physical characteristics with known cultivars to identify possible synonyms; (4) Search specialty nursery catalogs from Nuccio's Nurseries, Camellia Forest Nursery, or Loch Laurel Nursery. (Limited information available)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 2016; Upright and dense; ACS Registration #3017. The Camellia Journal,71(3):30 with name and color photo. American Camellia Yearbook, 2016, p. 140 with color photo and description. This 15-year-old C. japonica chance seedling of ‘Bob Hope’ first bloomed in 2008. This profuse bloomer falls in one piece and is long lasting with consistent.

This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #597 (1962); Ernest E. Judice; Upright and average density; American Camellia Yearbook, 1962-1963, p.219, Reg. No.597: A 10 years old chance japonica seedling that first bloomed 1958. Originated by Ernest E. Judice, New Orleans, Louisiana, USA. Plant growth is upright and average density. Leaves, 10 cm x 5.5 cm, serrated, dark green. The 12.5 cm x 7.5 cm flower is a loose, peony form, white with canary yellow petaloids. Mid-season flowering. See colour plate, front cover, ACS., 1962, The Camellia Journal, vol.17, No.1.
Notes: Gus Menard is a japonica camellia originated by Ernest E. Judice of New Orleans, Louisiana, USA, registered in 1962 (ACS Reg. No. 597). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. The flowers are anemone in form, displaying white coloring. Plant growth is upright and average density. As a japonica camellia, Gus Menard is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: SASANQUA.; Registered 1905; Sōjiro Saitō; Kaitsu-en, 1905, Chabaika Meikan; Nihon Shubyō Co. Catalogue, 1910, p.46: White stripes on red. First listing in English, Wada, 1941, Japanese Garden Treasures, p.32: Semi-double, red striped with white, very large. Satomi, 1958, Nomenclature List of Sasanqua of Japan: Pink slightly shaded white with margins a deeper pink. Large semi­double. For colour photos see: Encyclopedia of Camellias in Colour, vol.I, 1972, pl.550, p.216; Macoboy, 1981, The Colour Dictionary of Camellias, p.174. Chinese synonym: ‘Huaziman’. Differ­ent reading: ‘Hana Jiman’. A seedling.

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 2022; 25-year chance seedling; Upright, open growth, average growth rate; Isabel's Birthday (C. japonica). Registered in 2022. ACS Registration #3303. It was originated and registered by Pat B. Johnson from Cairo, Georgia, USA. A 25 year old chance seedling of C. japonica ' Snow Lady ’ . It was first bloomed in 2002. Flower semidouble to anemone to loose peony form, medium size, 9.5 cm in diameter, 7.0 cm in depth, light pink shading to hot pink on edges with yellow anthers and white filaments. Leaf medium green, 7.0 cm.

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1974; Compact stamen cylin­der with golden anthers and creamy filaments; Andoh, 1974, Tsubaki Nyūmon, black and white photo No.65, p.51. Yokoyama & Kirino, 1989, Nihon no Chinka, p.273. Seibundō Shinkōsha, 1979, Senchinshū, p.33, colour photo, p.206: Medium size, single, 8-9 cm across, 6-7 petals, purplish scarlet at haft, becoming closely veined and having a definite, white edge, flat with some fluting at apex. Compact stamen cylin­der.
Notes: Kakure-iso is a japonica camellia, registered in 1974. It is a sport of Nihon-no-homare. The flowers are single in form, displaying white coloring. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1951; Stowe, 1951, American Camellia Yearbook , p.282: Helen K is a gem amongst new camellias. It is an incomplete double, 10-11 cm across x 6 cm deep. Golden stamens are inter­mixed with the petals in the centre of the flower. The colouring of the petal base is white to deli­cate pink, darkening towards the petal tips, ending pale lavender. The plant is a fast, heavy grower and floriferous. Blooms early to mid-season. Originated in USA by J.L. Kahn, Pen­sacola, Florida.
Notes: Helen K. is a japonica camellia, registered in 1951. First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink coloring. Morgan’, ‘Doris Madalia’, ‘Herme-Sport’, ‘Herme Sport Number 2’, ‘Princess Lucille’, ‘Herme Variegated’, ‘Hikarugenji Variegated’, ‘Herme Variant’. Originated in the Kantō Dis­trict, Japan. Notes: Hikarugenji-yokomoku is a japonica camellia, registered in 1859. The flowers are peony in form, displaying white variegated coloring. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #384 (1998); New Zealand Camellia Bulletin, March 1998, Issue No.129, vol.XX No.4, p.20, Reg. No.384. Registered by J.R. Finlay, Whangarei, New Zealand. A cross between a seedling (C.japonica Mrs Bertha A. Harms x C.hybrid Salab) x C.lutchuensis hybrid Scentuous. A medium to large peony form , 10 cm diameter x 5 cm deep, which sometimes tends to a rose form double. Colour is bright pink shading deeper into the centre, with slight veining (RHS.CC. 62B shading to 55B). It has a moderate.
Notes: Nice Fragrance is a japonica camellia, registered in 1998 (ACS Reg. No. 384). The flowers are rose form double in form, displaying pink coloring. As a japonica camellia, Nice Fragrance is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. Plant growth is open and rapid with dark green leaves, sharply serrated, 15 cm long x 7. Foliage features dark green leaves, sharply serrated, 15 cm long x 7. The first character is different from that of the sasanqua so that it refers to the “Moon of the 15th day of the 8th lunar month and the 13th day of the 9th lunar month”. Originated in Japan. (Believed extinct.).

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1957; Pyron, 1957, Camellian, vol.VIII, No.2, p.6: A seedling of unknown parent­age named Honey Chile by Doxey, a former N.B.C. radio star. It is a large, brilliant red to deep red, with several, narrow, twisted petaloids interspersed with a crown of stamens. Around the stamens and mixed with the rabbit eared petals are 5 white, peculiarly shaped petaloids. Origi­nated in USA by W.D. Pleasant, Beaumont. Texas. Orthographic error: ‘Honey Child’.
Notes: Honey Chile is a japonica camellia, registered in 1957. The flowers are unknown in form, displaying white coloring. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1858; Medici Spada,1858, Delle Nuove Camellie...dalle Semine Romane, p.6. No description. van Houtte Catalogue, 1858, 72:15: Peony form, very large, brilliant red with flesh pink spots. Early flowering. Originated in Italy by Delgrande, Rome. There has been confusion in America where two other camellias were distributed under the same name so that the names Imperator (France), and Imperator (US) are used to distinguish them. Orthographic error: 'Imperatore'. Synonyms: 'Corrie Belle', 'Imperator' (France), 'Big Daddy'. Sport: Imperator Variegated. See p.104, Hertrich, Camellias.
Notes: Imperator is a japonica camellia, registered in 1858. The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink variegated coloring. Description: CULTIVAR NOT FOUND: No authoritative record located in the International Camellia Register or American Camellia Society Encyclopedia for 'Irrational Exuberance'. Verify spelling and check for possible synonyms or local designations.
Notes: Research was conducted for 'Irrational Exuberance' (listed locally as 'Irrational Exuberance' with epithet ''). The International Camellia Register (camellia.iflora.cn) was queried but returned no matching cultivar record. The American Camellia Society Encyclopedia was also checked without success. This cultivar may be an unregistered local selection, a seedling that was never formally registered, or it may be listed under a different name or spelling. Possible steps for verification: (1) Check ACS Yearbooks for historical registrations; (2) Contact the originator or local camellia society for provenance information; (3) Compare physical characteristics with known cultivars to identify possible synonyms; (4) Search specialty nursery catalogs from Nuccio's Nurseries, Camellia Forest Nursery, or Loch Laurel Nursery. (Limited information available)

Flowers large, 11 cm across, semi-double of clear rose, petals large, notched, rounded,.

The white variegation is moired. Blooms mid-season. See colour photo front cover, ACS, 1965, The Camellia Journal, vol.20, No.4. Synonym: ‘Magic City Variegated’. Orthographic error:.
Notes: Magic City is a japonica camellia originated by Dr Robert T. Cale of Hueytown, Alabama, USA, registered in 1966 (ACS Reg. No. 902). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Description: NON-RETICULATA HYBRID.; Registered 1695; The name ‘Hagoromo’ has been used for about 9 cultivars, some now extinct, including Itō, Ihei, 1695, Kadan Chikinshō: Persimmon pink, pointed petals, double. Iwasaki, 1821, Honzō: Cherry pink, formal double. Both different to the modern Hagoromo. Yashiro Kōken, 1841, Kokon Yōrankō, vol.311. No description; Kasuya, Kamegorō, 1859, Tsubaki Irohanayose Irotsuki lists three Hagoromo. One a single cherry pink, sake cup shape; the second one is a persimon pink, double, small; thought to be the same as Itōs; and finally.
Notes: Hagoromo is a non-reticulata hybrid camellia, registered in 1695. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying pink coloring. Awards and recognition: Award of Merit” in 1953 by the RHS; AGM (Award of Garden Merit) plant by the Royal Horticultural Society in 1993 at H5. As a non-reticulata hybrid camellia, Hagoromo is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Notes: Magnolia Queen Pink is a japonica camellia, registered in 1958. It is a sport of Priscilla Brooks as ‘Magnolia Queen’. The flowers are unknown in form, displaying pink coloring. Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #581 (1961); W.R Wilson Jr.; 9-year chance seedling, first bloomed 1957; Upright; American Camellia Yearbook, 1961, p.226. Reg. No.581: A 9 year old chance seedling of ‘Magnoliiflora’ (Hagoromo) that first bloomed 1957. Originated by W.R Wilson Jr., Hammond, Louisiana, USA. Plant growth is upright. open and medium in rate with mid­-green leaves, 7.5 cm x 3.8 cm. The anemone form flowers are miniature. 5-6 cm across x 2.5-3.2 cm deep. The flowers are white with yellow stamens and have 12 petals and 98 petaloids. Blooms mid-season. Won the “William E Wylam Miniature.
Notes: Man Size is a japonica camellia originated by W.R Wilson Jr. of Hammond, Louisiana, USA, registered in 1961 (ACS Reg. No. 581). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 9-year-old chance seedling that first bloomed in 1957. The flowers are anemone in form, displaying white coloring. Each bloom features 12 petals and 98 petaloids. Plant growth is upright. Foliage features green leaves, 7. As a japonica camellia, Man Size is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #54 (1963); A.M. Davis; ACRS., 1963, Camellia News, No.12, p.24, Reg. No.54: Originated by A.M. Davis, Cammaray, N.S.W., Australia. A sport of Aspasia Macarthur which originated in 1958. Except for colour the flower is a typical Aspasia Macarthur. Characteristics: Colour cream with the petals brilliantly edged with rose in the manner of the Azalea ‘Albert & Eliza­beth’. Sports: Margaret Davis Ashley, Margaret Davis Picotee. Orthographic error: ‘Mar­gareth Davis’. Received the “William Hertrich Award”, 1969; the “Sewell Mutant Award”, 1976 and the “William E. Woodroof,.
Notes: Margaret Davis is a japonica camellia originated by A.M. Davis of Cammaray, N, registered in 1963 (ACS Reg. No. 54). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook; pp.55 & 102. It is a sport of Aspasia Macarthur which originated in 1958. The flowers are peony in form, displaying red coloring. Awards and recognition: William Hertrich Award”, 1969; the “Sewell Mutant Award”, 1976 and the “William E; AGM (Award of Garden Merit) plant by the Royal Horticultural Society in 2012 at H5. As a japonica camellia, Margaret Davis is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1951; C.S. Tait Sr.; Open, some central petals tend to remain semi-erect; Fendig, 1951, American Camellia Catalogue with colour pl. as ‘Mar­garet Radcliffe’: Medium to large, delicate, shell-pink shading to white, semi-double, 10-11 cm across. Until fully open, some central petals tend to remain semi-erect. The petals are obovate and crinkle towards the tip. Filaments white, anthers yellow; bud long, oval and with pink tip. Leaves dark, dull green. oval. 7.5 cm long x 4 cm wide. short apex, prominent, raised veins, finely serrulate. Plant habit erect. vigorous and a profuse bloomer.
Notes: Margaret Ratcliffe is a japonica camellia originated by C.S. Tait Sr. of Brunswick, Georgia, USA, registered in 1951. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying red coloring. Growth is open, some central petals tend to remain semi-erect. As a japonica camellia, Margaret Ratcliffe is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Margaret Radcliff' and is registered as 'Margaret Ratcliffe'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

This very popular camellia has suffered innumerable misspelling of its name, including the following: ‘Margaret Carbone’, ‘Margarete Car­bon’, ‘Margarita Calcioni’, ‘Margarita Calceoni’, ‘Margarita Caleoni’, ‘Margarita Coleoni’, ‘Margarita Coleonie’, ‘Margarita Colsoni’, ‘Margharita’, ‘Margharita Calceomie’, ‘Margharita Caleone’, ‘Margharita.
Notes: Margherita Coleoni is a japonica camellia, registered in 1865. The flowers are formal double in form, displaying red variegated coloring. No.19, illustr. p.9: A chance C.japonica seedling thought to be from Spencer’s Pink. The plant is upright, sturdy and dense. The flowers are semi-double, 14-15 cm across by 5-6 cm deep. Their colour is Tyrian Rose, (HCC, 24/3) with gold anthers and white filaments fused at the base. Petals number 14-16. Originated in New Zealand by W.M. McFarland.
Notes: Billie McFarland is a japonica camellia, registered in 1963 (ACS Reg. No. 19). The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying white coloring. Growth is upright, sturdy and dense. As a japonica camellia, Billie McFarland is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #1886 (1983); Paul Gilley; Upright and average with dark green leaves 11 cm long x 5 cm wide
Notes: Mark Cannon is a japonica camellia originated by Paul Gilley of Grand Ridge, Florida, USA, registered in 1983 (ACS Reg. No. 1886). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. It arose as a chance seedling of Arch of Triumph that blooms mid­season to late. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying pink variegated coloring. Each bloom features 12 petals. Plant growth is upright and average with dark green leaves 11 cm long x 5 cm wide. Foliage features dark green leaves 11 cm long x 5 cm wide. Vigorous, compact, upright growth. Blooms mid-sea­son to late. Originated by Nuccio’s Nurseries, Altadena, California, USA. Received the “William E. Wylam Miniature Award” for 1975. Orthographic error: ‘Maroon Gold’.

The flowers are anemone in form, displaying white coloring. Each bloom features 8 petals and 70 petaloids. Foliage features dark green leaves 7 cm long x 3 cm wide. Awards and recognition: RHS. As a non-reticulata hybrid camellia, Marshmallow is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1891; Dean., A. Camellias, 1891, Gardeners’ Chronicle, ser.3, 9:404: Blush, very beautiful formal double. Received a First Class Certificate in 1891 when shown by Paul. The American Florist, 1891, April, 16, Vol.6, No.150,p.677. Originated in England. Orthographic variant: ‘Waltham Beauty’.

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #2603 (2003); Lyman L. Fillingame; Upright, spreading and of average growth rate; ACS, The Camellia Journal, Dec. 2003, p.21 with colour photo, Reg. No.2603. A sport of Marlena Bozeman, first observed in 1998, and which has flowered true for 5 years.The semi-double flower is deep red, blotched with white. Petals have heavy texture and are fimbriated. Originated by Lyman L. Fillingame, Purvis, Miss., USA. American Camellia Yearbook, p.64, colour photo p.c4. Flower measures 10 cm across x 5.7 cm deep, with 27 petals, 6 petaloids and yellow anthers. Plant is upright, spreading.
Notes: Mary Alice is a japonica camellia originated by Lyman L. Fillingame of Purvis, Miss, registered in 2003 (ACS Reg. No. 2603). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Each bloom features 27 petals and 6 petaloids with yellow anthers. Growth is upright, spreading and of average growth rate. Foliage features dark green leaves are 8. As a japonica camellia, Mary Alice is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. A remarkable anemone-form flower. The plant is of vigorous growth and a free and early bloomer. Rubel, 1928, Azaleas and Camellias from Longview Catalogue, p.4, fig. p.5 as ‘Prof. Sargent’: One of the best of the dark varieties, a rich deep crimson. Flowers are 8 cm in diameter, globular, solid and compactly built, usually has 12 wide, slightly rumpled guard petals.
Notes: Professor Sargent is a japonica camellia, registered in 1908. The flowers are peony in form, displaying dark red variegated coloring. Each bloom features 230 petals. Growth is vigorous growth and a free and early bloomer. As a japonica camellia, Professor Sargent is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Description: NON-RETICULATA HYBRID.; ACS #110 (1975); Upright, semi-spreading, foliage a dark green, 9 cm x 4 cm
Notes: Mary Phoebe Taylor is a non-reticulata hybrid camellia, registered in 1975 (ACS Reg. No. 110). The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink coloring. Each bloom features 14 petals and 60 petaloids with yellow anthers, cream filaments, 13. Growth is upright, semi-spreading, foliage a dark green, 9 cm x 4 cm. Awards and recognition: AGM (Award of Garden Merit) plant by the Royal Horticultural Society in 2002 at H5. As a non-reticulata hybrid camellia, Mary Phoebe Taylor is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1858; Vigorous, upright growth and large, light green leaves, smooth, leat; van Houtte Catalogue, 1858; Verschaffelt 1858, Nouvelle Iconographie, Book VI, pl.II. Found in a group of seedlings obtained by the late Mr Mathot of Ghent. Its blossoms of the largest size, are composed of very numerous, ample petals of equal size, ovate and almost pointed, of a snow white colouring and imbricated. This formal double camellia, about 10 cm across, is white with a rare pink fleck, vigorous, upright growth and large, light green leaves, smooth, leathery with obscure serrations.
Notes: Mathotiana Alba is a japonica camellia, registered in 1858. The flowers are formal double in form, displaying red variegated coloring. Growth is upright growth and large, light green leaves, smooth, leathery with obscure serrations. Foliage features light green leaves, smooth, leathery with obscure serrations. Buds round with.

Description: CULTIVAR NOT FOUND: No authoritative record located in the International Camellia Register or American Camellia Society Encyclopedia for 'Snow Camellia'. Verify spelling and check for possible synonyms or local designations.
Notes: Research was conducted for 'Snow Camellia' (listed locally as 'Osabaw Camellia' with epithet 'Snow Camellia'). This cultivar may be an unregistered local selection, a seedling that was never formally registered, or it may be listed under a different name or spelling. Possible steps for verification: (1) Check ACS Yearbooks for historical registrations; (2) Contact the originator or local camellia society for provenance information; (3) Compare physical characteristics with known cultivars to identify possible synonyms; (4) Search specialty nursery catalogs from Nuccio's Nurseries, Camellia Forest Nursery, or Loch Laurel Nursery. As the name ‘Mine-no-yuki’ has been used for earlier cultivars of C.japonica and C.sasanqua, for the Higo camellia the name has been prefixed with “Higo” to distinguish the cultivar. Thus Higo-mine-no-yuki is accepted as the valid name.

Leaves obovate to broad-elliptic, apex shortly cuspidate-acuminate, impressed venation, margins serrulate, 5.6 cm long x 3.8 cm wide: petioles 5 mm long, very hairy. Flower peony type, rosy red, (Cherry 722/2) with long, recurved, wavy and lobulate petals, 10-15 in number. Stamens in several groups arranged in double circles. Flowers mid-season to late. Found in the wild state in Toyama Prefecture, Japan. ‘Sasahara’ was the place of collection.
Notes: Sasahara is a japonica camellia, registered in 1968. The flowers are peony in form, displaying red coloring. As a japonica camellia, Sasahara is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Sadaharu Oh' and is registered as 'Sasahara'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #125 (1954); E.H. Harrell, Thomasville, Georgia; 5-year seedling; Compact; American Camellia Quarterly, 1954, vol.7, No.4, Reg. No.125: A 5 year old seedling of Mrs F.L. Gibson x Debutante, originated by E.H. Harrell, Thomasville, Georgia, USA. Plant growth is compact. Flower buds large and rounded with white colouration. Flow­ers incomplete double with mixed petaloids, resembling Debutante in shape, 10 cm across, white. Early flowering. Orthographic errors: ‘Sallie Harrill’, ‘Sally Hurrell’. See Sharp, 1951, Camellias Illustrated, p.91 for illustration. ACS, Reg. No. 125. American Camellia Yearbook, 1954. p331.
Notes: Sally Harrell is a japonica camellia originated by E.H. Harrell of Thomasville, Georgia, USA, registered in 1954 (ACS Reg. No. 125). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 5-year-old seedling. The flowers are anemone in form, displaying white coloring. Plant growth is compact. As a japonica camellia, Sally Harrell is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #562 (2006); Albert Raymond and Gwenda Norris; Bushy, dwarf plant; C.Aust., Camellia News, Autumn 2006, No.170, p.12, Reg. No. 562. Originated by Albert Raymond and Gwenda Norris, Capalaba, Qld, Australia. A chance seedling that first flowered in 1993. A loose peony, cyclamen pink flower of 20 petals and 25 petaloids, 7 cm across x 3 cm deep. Flowers heavily early to mid-season on a slow growing, bushy, dwarf plant. Leaves dark green, glossy, elongated and serrated, 5.5 cm x 2 cm. Flowers shatter. Chinese synonym ‘Gaier’.
Notes: Sandra Gail is a japonica camellia originated by Albert Raymond and Gwenda Norris of Capalaba, Qld, Australia, registered in 2006 (ACS Reg. No. 562). It arose as a chance seedling . The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink coloring. Each bloom features 20 petals and 25 petaloids. Growth is bushy, dwarf plant. As a japonica camellia, Sandra Gail is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Sandra Deal' and is registered as 'Sandra Gail'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 2020; Dr. Richard L. Guthrie of Auburn; Spreading; Samford Park ( C. japonica ) Registered in 2020. ACS Registration #3186.This 41 year-old C. japonica chanceseedling of ' Magnoliaeflora ' first bloomed in in the late 1980's. It wasoriginated by Dr. Richard L. Guthrie of Auburn, Alabama and registered byAuburn-Opelika Men's Camellia Club of Auburn, Alabama and propagated by KennethM. Rogers of Auburn, Alabama, USA. 【 Bloom 】 The medium to large sized 8.9cmx 3.8cm formal double form flower is clear pink fading to a pure white centerthird of.
Notes: Samford Park is a japonica camellia originated by Dr. Richard L. Guthrie of Auburn of Alabama and registered byAuburn, registered in 2020. The flowers are formal double in form, displaying graduated shading coloring. Growth is spreading. Foliage features dark green leaves average 8. As a japonica camellia, Samford Park is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1981; Macoboy, 1981. The Colour Dictionary of Camellias. p.30, where it is stated that it is a C.reticulata from China. Chinese synonym ‘Samohong’. Ferreira & Celina, 2000, O Mundo da Camélia, p.129 with colour photo; Carmine red, formal double, medium to large, flowers mid-season.
Notes: Satsuma-kurenai is a japonica camellia, registered in 1981. The flowers are formal double in form, displaying dark red coloring. As a japonica camellia, Satsuma-kurenai is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #350 (1959); K. Sawada, Crichton, Alabama; 12-year seedling, first bloomed 1953; American Camellia Yearbook, 1959, p.281, Reg. No.350: A 12 year old seedling of Imura x Dr W.G. Lee, originated by K. Sawada, Crichton, Alabama, USA, which first bloomed 1953. Plant growth is medium with thick green leaves, finely serrate with sharp apices. The full, formal double flower averages 10 cm across x 3.8 cm deep with 80-90 petals. The colour is white shading to a delicate pink on or about the outer third of the petals. Flowers mid-season to late.
Notes: Sawada's Dream is a japonica camellia originated by K. Sawada of Crichton, Alabama, USA, registered in 1959 (ACS Reg. No. 350). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 12-year-old seedling that first bloomed in 1953. The flowers are formal / tiered in form, displaying graduated shading coloring. Each bloom features 90 petals. Plant growth is medium with thick green leaves, finely serrate with sharp apices. Foliage features green leaves, finely serrate with sharp apices. As a japonica camellia, Sawada's Dream is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 2008; K. Sawada; Upright, vigorous plant; ACS, The Camellia Journal, June 2008, p.32 with colour photo, Regn No.2718; A chance seedling which first flowered in 1971. Originated by K. Sawada, Mobile, Ala., USA, and propagated by Bobby Green, Fairhope, Ala. The 10 cm diameter x 5 cm deep, anemone to peony form flower is dark red, and the petaloids are speckled with white. Flowers early to late. Upright, vigorous plant. American Camellia Yearbook, 2008, p.127 with colour photo; Dark green leaves are 10 cm x 5.
Notes: Sawada's Mahogany is a japonica camellia originated by K. Sawada of Mobile, Ala, registered in 2008. First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. It arose as a chance seedling . The flowers are peony in form, displaying white coloring. Growth is Upright, vigorous plant. Foliage features Dark green leaves are 10 cm x 5 cm. As a japonica camellia, Sawada's Mahogany is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: NON-RETICULATA HYBRID.; Registered 1832; Debonnaire, 1832, Annales de la Société d’Horticulture, Paris, 11:15-20: Leaves 8 cm x 5 cm, ovate, somewhat acuminate, venation apparent, mid-green; buds large, a little pointed, scales yellowish; flower 8 cm across, double, cherry-red, petals with nuances of red and rose, long, narrow but well imbricated. See illustration 654, Berlèse, 1841, Iconographie. Originated in England. Orthographic errors: ‘Scintilans’, ‘Scintillous’, ‘Scintillano’.
Notes: Scintillans is a non-reticulata hybrid camellia, registered in 1832. The flowers are unknown in form, displaying red coloring. As a non-reticulata hybrid camellia, Scintillans is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1989; Phillips & Rix, 1989, Shrubs, the Pan Gardens series, text, p.65, colour plate, p.64: Semi-double white. Originated in UK. Note: this name is invalid as already in use.

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1859; Kasuya, Kamegorō, 1859, Tsubaki Irohanayose Irotsuki, in section on early blooming; Nagoya Chinzue (ca.1910). Owned by Usami, Naohachi. For this see Kyōto Engei Kurabu, 1965, Tsubaki Tokushū, No.6, p.127. Large size, white, peony form camellia. Itō, Ko’emon, 1879, Chinkashū: White, formal double. Large peony form. Early blooming. There are many flowers forms for this cultivar, anemone form, formal double, semi­double. Resembles Shiro-daikagura. See colour pls. and descriptions: Tuyama, 1966, Camellia Cultivars of Japan, pl.65 & p.114; Andoh, 1971, Tsubaki, Meika.
Notes: Shirabyōshi is a japonica camellia, registered in 1859. The flowers are anemone in form, displaying white coloring. Morn / Shirabyoshi' and is registered as 'Shirabyōshi'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #209 (1953); Toichi Domoto; 3-year seedling; Opening; Fendig, 1953, American Camellia Catalogue: White. Incomplete double. Mid­season. American Camellia Yearbook, 1954, p.332, Reg. No.209: A 3 year old sport of C.M. Wilson that first flowered 1950. Originated by Toichi Domoto, Hayward, California, USA. Plant type and growth are the same as for Elegans. Flower incomplete double anemome form, simi­lar to Elegans. Colour white. Some petals show very light basal pink on first opening. Flowers mid-season. The name is formed from ‘Shiro’, Japanese for white and ‘Chan’ for Chandler.
Notes: Shiro Chan is a japonica camellia originated by Toichi Domoto of Hayward, California, USA, registered in 1953 (ACS Reg. No. 209). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 3-year-old seedling. It is a sport of C. The flowers are anemone in form, displaying pink coloring. Growth is opening. As a japonica camellia, Shiro Chan is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. Description: SASANQUA.; Registered 1841; Yashiro, 1841, Kokon Yōrankō, vol.311; Kasuya, Kamegorō, 1859, Tsubaki Irohanayose Irotsuki, in the section on peony form; Itō, Ko’emon, 1879, Chinkashū: Light rose-pink. Small to medium size, peony form. Tuyama. 1968, Camellias of Japan, pl.131, p.126, description, p.126 as ‘Shishi-gashira’: Leaves small, broadly elliptic to oblong elliptic, venation slightly impressed. Flowers pink (Carmine 621/2), anemone to peony form with 8-9 broadly expanded outer petals and small, erect, folded petals and petaloids forming a large, rounded mass in the centre. Flowers.
Notes: Shishigashira is a sasanqua camellia, registered in 1841. The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink coloring. As a sasanqua camellia, Shishigashira is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. Medium to small size. Originated in Japan. See: JCS., 1969, Tsubaki, No.7, p.31. (Believed extinct.).
Notes: Shikoku-sarasa is a sasanqua camellia, registered in 1695. The flowers are unknown in form, displaying white coloring. Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #2626 (2004); R.E. Dodd, Marshallville, Ga; Upright with average spreading growth; ACS, The Camellia Journal, Sept. 2004, p.29 with colour photo; Reg. No.2626. A chance seedling originated by R.E. Dodd, Marshallville, Ga., USA. First bloomed in the early 1990s. The magenta pink flower has 14-15 heart shaped petals with unusual brushed, lighter pink markings, bright yellow anthers and white filaments. Flowers mid-season to late. American Camellia Yearbook, 2004, p.95, colour photo p.c4. Plant is upright with average spreading growth. Dark green leaves are 9.5 cm long x 3.8 cm wide.
Notes: Shirley Meneice is a japonica camellia originated by R.E. Dodd of Marshallville, Ga, registered in 2004 (ACS Reg. No. 2626). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. It arose as a chance seedling . The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying white coloring. Growth is upright with average spreading growth. Foliage features Dark green leaves are 9. As a japonica camellia, Shirley Meneice is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. (Gene Phillips)' and is registered as 'Shirley Meneice'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 2025; Vigorous growth rate, upright, open growth; Show Me （ C. japonica ） Registered in 2025. ACS Registration #3398. It was originated and registered by Tommy Alden from Byron, Georgia, USA. A 9-year-old Seedling of Japonica 'Lady in Pink'. It was first bloomed in 2019. Flower Semidouble to loose peony form with occasional petaloids and petals may have a narrow white picotee edge, medium pink with yellow anthers and white filaments. large size, 12.7 cm in diameter. Leaf , 11.4 cm long and 7.0 cm wide. Plant.
Notes: Show Me is a japonica camellia, registered in 2025. The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink coloring. Growth is vigorous growth rate, upright, open growth. As a japonica camellia, Show Me is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Originated in France by Prosper Nerriére, 1843 as ‘Prince de Joinville’. Orthographic errors: ‘Prince d’Joinville’, ‘Principe di Joinville’.

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1970; Vigorous, upright plant; Goertz, 1970, American Camellia Yearbook, p.25: A C.japonica seedling, 13 cm across, irregular semi-double, white bloom. Flowers midseason on a vigorous, upright plant. Originated at Nuccio’s Nurseries, Altadena, California, USA. Nuccio’s #6503. See colour photo, p.117, Macoboy, 1981, The Colour Dictionary of Camellias. Chinese synonym: ‘Yinlangtao’.
Notes: Silver Waves is a japonica camellia, registered in 1970. First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying white coloring. American Camellia Yearbook, 1987, p.94. The 4 year old seedling first bloomed 1982. Average size flower, 14 cm across with irregular, lacy petals. Plant growth is upright, dense and rapid. Chinese synonym: ‘Yin­choudai’.

Description: SASANQUA.; ACS #2570 (2002); Nuccio; Dense, with excellent columnar growth, and dark green leaves 3

It arose as a chance seedling. The flowers are single in form, displaying pink coloring. Each bloom features 9 petals. Growth is dense, with excellent columnar growth, and dark green leaves 3. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1956; Compact growth; SCCS., 1956, The Camellia. Its Culture and Nomenclature, p.85: White. See colour photo, front cover, SCCS., 1959, The Camellia Review, vol.20, No.7. Colour photo, (p.100), Adachi, 1960, Camellia. Its Appreciation and Artistic Arrangement.

Description: JAPONICA.; ACS #758 (1965); Wilmer Stewart, Savannah, Georgia; 6-year chance seedling, first bloomed 1961; Upright, rapid and spreading with dark green leaves, 10 cm long x 3
Notes: Snowman is a japonica camellia originated by Wilmer Stewart of Savannah, Georgia, USA, registered in 1965 (ACS Reg. No. 758). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 6-year-old chance seedling that first bloomed in 1961. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying white coloring. Each bloom features 35 petals and 12 petaloids with yellow anthers. Plant growth is upright, rapid and spreading with dark green leaves, 10 cm long x 3. Foliage features dark green leaves, 10 cm long x 3. Awards and recognition: Award of the ACS for 1976. As a japonica camellia, Snowman is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: NON-RETICULATA HYBRID.; Registered 1965; Nuccio; Vigorous, upright growth; Nuccio’s Nurseries Catalogue, 1965: Pale pink with deeper pink towards the margin. Medium to large size, loose, peony form double. Vigorous, upright growth. Early to mid-season flowering. See colour photo No.10, p.25, Encyclopedia of Camellias in Colour, vol.II, 1978. Orthographic error: ‘Berenice Beautiful’, ‘Bernice Beauty’. Originated by Nuccio’s Nurseries, Altadena, California, USA.
Notes: Berenice Beauty is a non-reticulata hybrid camellia originated by Nuccio of Altadena, California, USA, registered in 1965. The flowers are peony in form, displaying pink coloring. Stanley, Magee, Bogalusa, LA and propagated by Ray Gentry, Jackson, MS. Flower has no markings other than soft pink coloring. Commercially introduced in 1979. Description: CULTIVAR NOT FOUND: No authoritative record located in the International Camellia Register or American Camellia Society Encyclopedia for 'Wendall's Dream'. Verify spelling and check for possible synonyms or local designations.
Notes: Research was conducted for 'Wendall's Dream' (listed locally as 'Wendall's Dream' with epithet ''). The International Camellia Register (camellia.iflora.cn) was queried but returned no matching cultivar record. The American Camellia Society Encyclopedia was also checked without success. This cultivar may be an unregistered local selection, a seedling that was never formally registered, or it may be listed under a different name or spelling. Possible steps for verification: (1) Check ACS Yearbooks for historical registrations; (2) Contact the originator or local camellia society for provenance information; (3) Compare physical characteristics with known cultivars to identify possible synonyms; (4) Search specialty nursery catalogs from Nuccio's Nurseries, Camellia Forest Nursery, or Loch Laurel Nursery. (Limited information available)

Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1895; Vigorous, open, upright, growth; Yokohama Nursery Co. Ltd. Catalogue, 1895: Double, white ball. Note: This appears to be the origin of Shiratama as it is known in the West. According to SCCS., 1950. The Camellia. Its Culture and Nomenclature, p.60 as ‘Shirotama’ its description is: White. Medium sized, rose form to formal double. Vigorous, open, upright, growth. Midseason blooming. However, in Japan ‘Shiratama’ is a white single, never double. Synonyms: ‘Egret’, ‘Hearn’s Egret’, ‘Abundance’, ‘Senyōhaku’. Yashiro, 1841, Kokon Yōrankō cites Honzō Kōmoku Keimō 1803.
Notes: Shiratama is a japonica camellia, registered in 1895. The flowers are single in form, displaying white coloring. Growth is Vigorous, open, upright, growth. Description: JAPONICA.; Registered 1986; David L. Feathers; Dense bush, taller than wide; Trehane Nursery Catalogue, 1986: (Feathers 1005) A sister seedling to Bridal Gown with broader leaves than most C.x williamsii, 12.5 cm x 5 cm, on a strong, dense bush, taller than wide. Full, peony flowers, 10 cm across, resmbling its parent Debutante with a light honey colour fading to white or flesh pink. Broad, rounded, outer petals, surrounding smaller petals and petaloids. Mid-season to late flowering. Originated by David L. Feathers, Lafayette, California, USA.

Flowers anemone form, white with red dots, medium size, over 8 cm diameter, outer petals broadly rotund, flat, emarginate, inner petals irregular or wavy, becoming smaller to the center. Description: Registered 1833; F. Amatuer, Correspondance des Plantes, 1833, Magazin d’Horticulture 1 [pt,E]:41: Louvain 1st Dec.1832. This camellia, together with ‘Doncke­laeri’ (Masayoshi), Ochroleuca and Tricolor (‘Ezo-nishiki’), arrived in Holland from Japan in 1829 and were first grown by Donckelaer and was the second of this group to flower. Notes: Pink Parade is a japonica camellia originated by E.D. Hudson of Hemet, California, USA, registered in 1974 (ACS Reg. No. 1275). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Originated by Dr Howard Smith, Gainesville, Fla., USA. American Camellia Yearbook, 2000, p.6, colour photo p.c13. The 20 year old seedling first flowered in 1990. Flower has 9 petals, 10 petaloids, and yellow anthers. Average flower size is 10 cm across x 6.5 cm deep.

Description: Registered 1855; Opened easily and contrasted with the dark green of its medium s; Verschaffelt, 1855, Nouvelle Iconographie, Book 4, pl.2: Most beautiful amongst the perfectly imbricated white varieties, due to the correct imbrication of its numerous, small, well-shaped petals of purest white, forming blooms larger than average. We obtained it from seed ourselves and seen it bloom in the spring of 1853. Its profuse flowering is especially remarkable, our parent plant had about 50 blooms at one time, which opened easily and contrasted with the dark green of its medium size, compact foliage.
Notes: Alba Elegantissima is a japonica camellia, registered in 1855. The flowers are formal double in form, displaying white coloring. Notes: Winter's Fire is a ornamental camellia originated by William L. Ackerman of Ashton, Maryland, USA, registered in 1993 (ACS Reg. No. 2271). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Buds: Elliptical. Petals: About 7, roughly trun­cate, margins deeply scalloped. Centre of flower: A small cluster of stamens, creamy white filaments 1.5cm long, small yellow anthers. Leaves: Elliptic, semi-glossy, dark green, leathery, 5.7 cm long x 2-3 cm wide, margins crenate, apices tapered, venation pronounced on upper sur­face. Plant habit spreading, free flowering, early. Originated in USA as a seedling from Coolidge.

Description: ACS #1717 (1981); G.F. Abendroth; 8-year seedling, first bloomed 1977; American Camellia Yearbook, 1981, p.104, Reg. No.1717: Medium to large, white, shaded to blush pink with occasional red lines or dashes; anemone form, C.japonica chance seedling. Originated by G.F. Abendroth, Shreveport, Louisiana, USA. Blooms early to mid-season. The 8 year old seedling first bloomed 1977. Average size, 12.5 cm across x 7.5 cm deep with 35-40 petals; petaloids and stamens numerous, yellow anthers, white filaments. Plant growth average with light green leaves, 10 cm x 6 cm. See colour photo.
Notes: Rachel Tarpy is a japonica camellia originated by G.F. Abendroth of Shreveport, Louisiana, USA, registered in 1981 (ACS Reg. No. 1717). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 8-year-old seedling that first bloomed in 1977. The flowers are anemone in form, displaying red variegated coloring. Each bloom features 40 petals with yellow anthers, white filaments. Plant growth average with light green leaves, 10 cm x 6 cm. Foliage features light green leaves, 10 cm x 6 cm. As a japonica camellia, Rachel Tarpy is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. Description: ACS #460 (1995); T.J. Savige; Vigorous growing, spreading plant; ACRS, Camellia News, 1995, No.135, p.13, Reg. No.460: Originated by T.J. Savige, Wirlinga, NSW, Australia. A chance C.japonica seedling that first flowered 1972. A red (RHS.CC.52C), informal double to anemone form of 25-30 petals and 35-45 petaloids; 12 cm across x 4 cm deep. Flowers mid-season to late on a vigorous growing, spreading plant. Leaves deep green, semi-matt, round to wide elliptic, shallowly serrate, apices acute, 7 cm long x 5 cm wide. Petals large, round and veined. Filaments scattered.

Description: CULTIVAR NOT FOUND: No authoritative record located in the International Camellia Register or American Camellia Society Encyclopedia for 'Dominic DiMatasso'. Verify spelling and check for possible synonyms or local designations.
Notes: Research was conducted for 'Dominic DiMatasso' (listed locally as 'Dominic DiMatasso' with epithet ''). The International Camellia Register (camellia.iflora.cn) was queried but returned no matching cultivar record. The American Camellia Society Encyclopedia was also checked without success. This cultivar may be an unregistered local selection, a seedling that was never formally registered, or it may be listed under a different name or spelling. Possible steps for verification: (1) Check ACS Yearbooks for historical registrations; (2) Contact the originator or local camellia society for provenance information; (3) Compare physical characteristics with known cultivars to identify possible synonyms; (4) Search specialty nursery catalogs from Nuccio's Nurseries, Camellia Forest Nursery, or Loch Laurel Nursery. (Limited information available)

Description: Registered 2001; Hybrid: C. hybrid (Fragrant One x C. yuhsienensis); Upright medium growth rate and dark green leaves 7 x 5cm
Notes: Fragrant Burgundy is a ornamental camellia, registered in 2001. This is a hybrid of C. hybrid (Fragrant One x C. yuhsienensis). The flowers are peony in form, displaying red coloring. Each bloom features 12 petals and 7 petaloids. Notably, this cultivar produces fragrant burgundy (non reticulata hybrid). Growth is upright medium growth rate and dark green leaves 7 x 5cm. Foliage features dark green leaves 7 x 5cm. Awards and recognition: RHS 53C peony flower of size 9 cm. As a ornamental camellia, Fragrant Burgundy is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. Description: Registered 1898; Spreading, medium vigorous and blooms heavily; Ashizawa, Yagorō, 1898, Chabaika Taishū; Yoko­hama Gardener’s Association, 1891, Descriptive Catalogue, p.9 as ‘Minenoyuki’: Early, snow-­white, double, profuse bloomer, often giving 100-150 buds on one plant. Petals are thin with a tendency to a square shape, 3.8 cm wide with two distinct lobes at apex, crinkled and folded. Some yellow filaments with orange anthers intermixed with petaloids. Buds round with.

Description: Registered 1942; Magnolia Gardens and Nursery Catalogue, 1942-1943: White, medium sized semi-double. Leaves, dark green, narrowly-ellip­tic, 8cm x 3.2cm; stiff texture, apex long and thin, tapered base, obscure venation, shallow ser­rations. Plant habit,.

Grown as a 14-year-old seedling. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying pink variegated coloring. Each bloom features 30 petals. Growth is Vigorous, open, pendulous growth. Foliage features dark green leaves average 16 cm long x 8 cm wide. Awards and recognition: RHS, FCC, 1969; AGM (Award of Garden Merit) plant by the Royal Horticultural Society in 1993 at H5. As a japonica camellia, Drama Girl is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: ACS #458 (1960); Jon C. Campbell, Natchez, Mississippi; 14-year chance seedling; American Camellia Yearbook,1960, p.195, Reg. No.458: A 14 year old chance seedling, originated by Jon C. Campbell, Natchez, Mississippi, USA, that first bloomed in 1949. Plant growth is of average density and medium rapid rate. Dark green leaves average 12.5 cm long by 6 cm wide. The dark red, single blooms are 10 cm across and 2 cm deep with 6 petals and creamy-red stamens. Flowers early to mid-season.
Notes: Christmas Bells is a japonica camellia originated by Jon C. Campbell of Natchez, Mississippi, USA, registered in 1960 (ACS Reg. No. 458). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Description: Registered 1990; Tadao; Hybrid: C. japonica × C. chrysantha; JSC, Japan Camellia, No.36, Oct.1990, p.4: A seedling of C.japonica ‘Haku-arashi-saga’ x C.chrysantha. Flower colour is pale yellow, of the same degree as Shokō, pale pink in the bud. Size of flower, 5 cm across, single, cup-shaped. Leaves similar to C.japonica, 13 cm long x 5 cm wide. Blooms early. Proved fertile. Originated by Tadao, Yamaguchi, Tsurugi-chō, Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan. Named and released in 1990.

Description: ACS #2000 (1986); Jane and George Griffin; 10-year seedling, first bloomed 1978; American Camellia Yearbook, 1986, p.91, Reg. The 10 year old seedling first bloomed 1978. Aver­age flower size is 6 cm across x 3.7 cm deep with 50 petals and 8-10 petaloids. Plant growth is erect and medium in rate with 7.5 cm x 3.7 cm, dark green leaves. Chinese synonym: 'Gelifen'.
Notes: Jane Griffin is a japonica camellia originated by Jane and George Griffin of Nashville, Tennissee, USA, registered in 1986 (ACS Reg. No. 2000). La Canada, California who acquired it from a Japanese grower who imported it to America from Japan in 1931. There may be a prior Japanese.

Notes: Lavender Prince II is a ornamental camellia originated by Dr Clifford Parks of Chapel Hill, North Carolina, USA, registered in 1982 (ACS Reg. No. 1780). Henderson Nursery Catalogue, 1867, p.33. No description. Linden Catalogue, 1871-1872. A large pink flower, tipped and edged white. Of European origin. [from] Ludicke, Belgium . The variety was imported by McIlhenny from Seidel to the USA about 1937. However, in America, the name has been erroneously applied to a variety originating in Magnolia Gardens. No.28, American Camellia Yearbook, 1954. See black and white photo, p.226, Hertrich, 1955, Camellias in the Huntington Gardens, vol.II. Sport: Martha Brice Variegated. Description: CULTIVAR NOT FOUND: No authoritative record located in the International Camellia Register or American Camellia Society Encyclopedia for 'Les Marbury Blush1 Fl'. Verify spelling and check for possible synonyms or local designations.
Notes: Research was conducted for 'Les Marbury Blush1 Fl' (listed locally as 'Les Marbury Blush1 Fl' with epithet ''). The International Camellia Register (camellia.iflora.cn) was queried but returned no matching cultivar record. The American Camellia Society Encyclopedia was also checked without success.
