Description: Registered 1834; J.E. von Reider, 1834, Die Beschreibung und Kultur der Azaleen, Cactus, Camelien..., p.220. No description. James Burnett ed., 1837, The Magazine of Botany and Gardening..., vol.3, new series, p.153: In addition to ‘Speciosa’ syn. ‘Rawesiana’, Rossii of France and ‘Rawes Variegated Camellia’ there is also listed a Speciosa in French catalogues. A large, dark crimson, sin­gle camellia; a Mertens & Fontaine, Collection de cent espèces.....camellia, 1845, pl.64. The flower measures 7.5 cm. The 4 exterior rows of petals are overlapping,.
Notes: Speciosa is a japonica camellia, registered in 1834. The flowers are unknown in form, displaying red variegated coloring. As a japonica camellia, Speciosa is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: ACS #318 (1984); Edgar Sebire; Upright, open plant has dark green, 14; ACRS, 1984, Camellia News, No.91, p.22, Reg. No.318: Originated by Edgar Sebire, Wandin North, Victoria, Australia. A seed from Lasca Beauty planted 1979, flowered 1982. The 15 cm diameter, light red, semi-double to informal double flowers are produced mid-season. The upright, open plant has dark green, 14.5 cm x 9.5 cm, leaves with prominent veining, numerous shallow serrations and an acuminate apex.
Notes: Bright Beauty is a reticulata hybrid camellia originated by Edgar Sebire of Wandin North, Victoria, Australia, registered in 1984 (ACS Reg. No. 318). The flowers are formal double in form, displaying red coloring. Growth is upright, open plant has dark green, 14. As a reticulata hybrid camellia, Bright Beauty is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Big Beauty' and is registered as 'Bright Beauty'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: Registered 1858; van Houtte Catalogue, 1858, 72:16: Imbricated, tricolor, very large flower. Van Houtte, 1860, Flore des Serres, vol.13, F.1323 as ‘Contessa Lavinia Maggi’: A large, magnificently imbricated flower, having round, fat buds, numerous petals, pure white ground with definite dashes of dark carmine. See also pl.105, The Floral Magazine, 1862, vol.2. Ortho­graphic errors: ‘Lavinia Moggi’, ‘La Vina Maggi’, ‘Lavinia Maggie’, ‘Contessa Lawinia Maggi’, ‘Lavina Maggi’, ‘Lafina Maggi’, ‘Livinia Maggi’, ‘Lavinia Maggie’, La Vinia Maggi’, ‘Contessa Livinia Maggi’. Synonym: ‘Contessa Lavinia Maggi’.
Notes: Lavinia Maggi is a japonica camellia, registered in 1858. The flowers are formal double in form, displaying red coloring. Awards and recognition: RHS; AGM (Award of Garden Merit) plant by the Royal Horticultural Society in 1993 at H5. As a japonica camellia, Lavinia Maggi is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Contessa Lavina Maggi' and is registered as 'Lavinia Maggi'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: Registered 1861; Vervaene; Lemaire, 1861, L’Illustration Horticole, vol.8, pl.299: Originated by Vervaene, Ledeberg, Belgium. A formal double of delicate, soft pink from the centre to the periphery. Its numerous petals are rounded and bilobate towards the exterior and oval and entire towards the centre. It was described in vol.4, The Floral Magazine, 1865 as ‘blush’ and van Houtte, 1873-1874 Catalogue and Rollisson’s Plant catalogue, 1877-1878 as ‘delicate, clear rose’. Illustrated in Urquhart’s The Camellia, 1956, it is reported to be a sport of.
Notes: Reine des Beautés is a japonica camellia originated by Vervaene of Ledeberg, Belgium, registered in 1861. It is a sport of the old American vari­ety Mrs Abby Wilder but no mention of this is made in the early descriptions. The flowers are formal double in form, displaying pink coloring. As a japonica camellia, Reine des Beautés is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Reine Des Beautes' and is registered as 'Reine des Beautés'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: Registered 1932; Spreading, willowy and medium in rate; The Jennings Nursery Co., Inc. 1932, catalogue, from Jennings, Louisiana. McIlhenny, 1934, List of Camellias for Sale, p.1: Pure red, irregular dou­ble, blotched white, 10.5 cm across x 5 cm deep. There are two rows of large petals, outer row consisting of 9. The centre is made up of a few large petals mixed with petaloids and some sta­mens. Leaves, dark green, twisted, 7.5 cm x 5 cm. Plant growth wide, spreading, willowy and medium in rate. The original plant.
Notes: Governor Mouton is a japonica camellia, registered in 1932. First published in the American Camellia Yearbook and Gerbing. The flowers are peony in form, displaying white variegated coloring. Plant growth wide, spreading, willowy and medium in rate. As a japonica camellia, Governor Mouton is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Governor Moutan' and is registered as 'Governor Mouton'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: Registered 1912; Spreading and vigorous tree; Taniguchi, 1912, Chinka Kyōkan: Deep pink. Large. Adachi, 1960, Camellia. Its Appreciation and Artistic Arrangement, p.59 colour photo, p.71, description as Hinomaru; Hiratsuka, 1964, Higo Camellia, p.27 & 12 & Tuyama, 1968, Camellias of Japan, pl.173, description, p.140 as ‘Hi-no-maru’: Flower cinnabar red, 7-10 cm across, single, 6 petal, a little wavy. Stamens, pale red filaments, 120-150 in number; pistil pro­truding above the stamens. Flowers late. Leaves medium size, flat, ovate to broadly elliptic, thick, rounded at the base, apex.
Notes: Hinomaru is a ornamental camellia, registered in 1912. The flowers are single in form, displaying dark red coloring. Each bloom features 6 petals. Growth is spreading and vigorous tree. As a ornamental camellia, Hinomaru is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. This cultivar is suitable for both landscape use and exhibition, contributing reliable blooms during the camellia season. Note: This cultivar is listed in the local collection as 'Japanese Fantasy' and is registered as 'Hinomaru'. (Source: International Camellia Register)

Description: ACS #1977 (1985); Dr M.D. Wine, Thomasville, Georgia; 10-year seedling; Upright and medium with dark green leaves, 11 cm x 5 cm
Notes: Tar Baby is a japonica camellia originated by Dr M.D. Wine of Thomasville, Georgia, USA, registered in 1985 (ACS Reg. No. 1977). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 10-year-old seedling. The flowers are anemone in form, displaying red coloring. Each bloom features 15 petals with red anthers, white filaments. Plant growth is upright and medium with dark green leaves, 11 cm x 5 cm. Foliage features dark green leaves, 11 cm x 5 cm. As a japonica camellia, Tar Baby is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: ACS #2212 (1991); Frank Pursel; 16-year seedling; Upright and medium in rate with dark green leaves 10 cm long x 4
Notes: Pearl S Buck is a ornamental camellia originated by Frank Pursel of Oakland, California, USA, registered in 1991 (ACS Reg. No. 2212). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. Grown as a 16-year-old seedling. The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying dark red coloring. Each bloom features 25 petals. Growth is upright and medium in rate with dark green leaves 10 cm long x 4. Foliage features dark green leaves 10 cm long x 4. As a ornamental camellia, Pearl S Buck is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Description: ACS #698 (1961); Compact, upright and vigorous plants; Nuccio’s Nurseries Catalogue, 1961: Blush pink, semi-double to peony form. American Camellia Yearbook, 1965, p.226, Reg. No.698: 3SCCS. No.62-344. A chance seedling that first bloomed 1956. Originated at Nuccio’s Nurseries, Altadena, California, USA. Colour, blush pink edged deeper pink, semi-double to peony form. Flowers up to 12.5 cm across. Blooms mid-season on compact, upright and vigorous plants.
Notes: Alexis Smith is a japonica camellia, registered in 1961 (ACS Reg. No. 698). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. It arose as a chance seedling . The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying pink coloring. Growth is compact, upright and vigorous plants. As a japonica camellia, Alexis Smith is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions. It performs best in partial shade with acidic, well-drained soil rich in organic matter. Regular mulching helps maintain the shallow root system, and protection from harsh afternoon sun preserves flower quality. Description: ACS #882 (1966); Robert V. Burgess; American Camellia Yearbook, 1966, p.84, Reg. No.882: A semi-double, chance seedling that first bloomed 1961 at the age of 15 years. Originated by Robert V. Burgess, Georgia, USA. Its colour is blush with cherry-red stripes and bright yellow stamens. Size 14.5 cm across and 7.5 cm deep. It has 16 petals and 16 erect rabbit ears, interspersed with 10 groups of stamens. Blooms mid-season.
Notes: Betty Burgess is a japonica camellia originated by Robert V. Burgess of Georgia, USA, registered in 1966 (ACS Reg. No. 882). First published in the American Camellia Yearbook. It arose as a chance seedling . The flowers are semi-double in form, displaying red coloring. Each bloom features 16 petals. As a japonica camellia, Betty Burgess is valued for its ornamental qualities in gardens across temperate regions.
